moves.3... a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5: To stop Bg4 before it happens.
moves.11... Bf8: To add more support on e5. I was planning Bxf7+, Kxf7, and then Ng5+ and get a superior position, but black has some defenses. i just play Ng5 to misplace the rook.
moves.12. Ng5 Re7 13. d5: To make the misplaced rook more of an advantage to me.
moves.13... Nb8 14. Nf1 c6: This move I overlooked. Now my e-pawn will become weak and the d-file will be in black's favor.
moves.17. Nf3: My knight serves no purpose on g5 anymore.
moves.17... Bg7 18. Bg5 Qc7 19. Bxf6: This move makes it easier to outpost on d5.
moves.19... Bxf6 20. Nf1: To do Ne3 and get to d5.
moves.20... Rd8 21. Ne3 Na5: To attack the bishop and protect d5.
moves.26... Kh8 27. b3 Nb6: I must now relinquish my outpost.
moves.29... Rdc8 30. cxb5 axb5 31. Rd5: To attack b5 and later attack d6.
moves.31... Rc5 32. Red1 Bf8 33. Rxc5: I was going crazy with trading this game.
moves.33... dxc5: Not Qxc5 due to Rd5 winning b5.
moves.34... Bd6: Perhaps better would be Qb8, protecting b5 and e5.
moves.35. Qd2: Applying pressure on d6. Moving the bishop out would be best.
moves.36. Ng5 Rf6 37. Rxd6: Here, black resigned. The lesson here is to understand the importance of weak squares and how to make use of them.
